verification_notes: The map \(\omega(p,q)=\det[p;q;c;d]\) is linear in each of \(p,q\), hence bilinear, and swapping \(p,q\) flips determinant sign, hence alternating. For rank: \(\omega(v,\cdot)=0\) iff \(\det[v,\cdot,c,d]\equiv 0\). If \(c,d\) are linearly independent, this kernel is exactly \(\mathrm{span}\{c,d\}\), so the kernel has dimension 2 in \(\mathbb R^4\), giving rank 2. This matches the “simple 2-form” viewpoint (up to Hodge star identification). Without independence of \(c,d\), rank drops to 0.

Then \(\ker\omega=\mathrm{span}\{c,d\}\) and \(\operatorname{rank}(\omega)=2\).” Also clarify whether you identify \(\omega\) with \(* (c\wedge d)\) or with the contraction \(\iota_d\iota_c\,\mathrm{vol}\).

verification_notes: The core linear-algebra claim is correct under standard assumptions: if a bilinear form is represented as \(\omega(u,v)=u^T\Omega v\) with \(\mathrm{rank}(\Omega)\le 2\), then for any three \(p_m\) and three \(q_n\), the matrix \(W=[\omega(p_m,q_n)]\) factors as \(W=P\Omega Q^T\), so \(\mathrm{rank}(W)\le 2\), hence every \(3\times 3\) determinant is zero. The degree-3 statement is also correct for the determinant in the nine entries \(\omega(p_m,q_n)\), and is degree-3 in underlying unknowns if each entry is linear in those unknowns.

verification_notes: The separable form is correct: if \(\Lambda_{mn}=u_{a_m}v_{b_n}w_gx_d\) with fixed \(g,d\), then \(\Lambda=(w_gx_d)\,\alpha\beta^T\) where \(\alpha_m=u_{a_m}\), \(\beta_n=v_{b_n}\), so \(\operatorname{rank}(\Lambda)\le 1\) (equal to 1 only if both vectors are nonzero and scalar \(w_gx_d\neq0\)). Also \((\Lambda\circ\Omega)_{mn}=\alpha_m\beta_n\Omega_{mn}\), hence \(M=\mathrm{diag}(\alpha)\,\Omega\,\mathrm{diag}(\beta)\). From this, \(\operatorname{rank}(M)=\operatorname{rank}(\Omega)\) requires both diagonal scalings invertible (all \(\alpha_m,\beta_n\neq0\)); otherwise only \(\operatorname{rank}(M)\le \operatorname{rank}(\Omega)\). So the equality claim is missing a nonvanishing assumption. The vanishing-determinant conclusion still follows from \(\operatorname{rank}(M)\le2<3\).
